name: places/ChIJCcPihlFYwokRmEIEZx7UTS8
formattedAddress: 423 W 46th St, New York, NY 10036, USA
adrFormatAddress: 423 W 46th St, New York, NY 10036-3510, USA

editorialSummary.text: Long-running Off-Broadway theater in a church presenting musicals & plays for 50+ years.

originalText.text:
What an awesome Off-Broadway venue this is. Great location. Easy and quick communication with Dan, the Director. Spacious dressing rooms. The light board is a bit outdated but can be replaced with a rental for the duration of the show. Big, big house, with 144 seats and a possibility to expand to 161! Very sizable stage - wide, deep, and really high!
If you can get in here for a show - do it!

originalText.text: Loved how intimate and great the sound was, the ambience, fhe old structures, were quite an experience. Went to watch " star without a name " play and it was superb, the actors played their best, lighting, sounds, and how close you are from the stage, gives you intense experience of a play. Restrooms are downstairs men and women separated.

originalText.text: Went to see Eisenhower here. Cool intimate space. We were on the last row but still had great views of the stage.

text.text: Went to see Eisenhower here. Cool intimate space. We were on the last row but still had great views of the stage.

originalText.text: We were near the front of the tiered seats,  making the magnificent performance of "Eisenhower" a once in a lifetime experience. The seating in general was excellent for viewing the play. The set,  the scenery,  the staff,  the convenience of attending were all wonderful. Very nice place to take in a play.

text.text: We were near the front of the tiered seats,  making the magnificent performance of "Eisenhower" a once in a lifetime experience. The seating in general was excellent for viewing the play. The set,  the scenery,  the staff,  the convenience of attending were all wonderful. Very nice place to take in a play.

originalText.text: We went to see Eisenhower at a matinee on August 12. There  should be a warning that the many are steepto get to any seats in the theater or the rest room in the basement. A tall man blocked much of my view for the first act. We moved two rows back to a row that was totaly empty. A combative manager and her assistant challenged anyone who moved to an open seat. The theater was little more than half full. When we told her we would not return to a limited view seat she pointed to another seat that was equally bad. She was combative, inflexible and spoiled any joy we had in continuing  watch the play. We left before the second act.We have lived in NYC since 1970 and have been to many off-broadway and off broadway theaters. The staff at St Clemens and the theater is at the bottom of of our list of awful thetare experiences. He even beat the time I had a rat run on my shoulder in a balconey seat at a village off-broadway theater. For older individuals, who dislike many steep chairs and rude combative theater staff, I recommend you avoid this venue,.
